newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU says US action against meat exports unjustified.
newsitem.headline: EU says US action against meat exports unjustified.

text.p: The European Union said on Tuesday that United States tit-for-tat action against its meat exports was unjustified on health grounds and regrettable.

Washington's move, imposing new inspection requirements that threaten to cut off some $300 million in annual meat imports from the EU, followed controls by Brussels on imports of U.S. poultry meat and fuelled prospects of a bitter trade war.
"There's no justification for any of this action on health grounds and this is a health matter," European Commission agriculture spokesman Gerard Kiely said. "It's a very regrettable move."

EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler, stung by criticism that the EU's executive gave priority to protecting the beef market instead of consumers during the mad cow crisis, is anxious to be seen to be safeguarding public health.

Kiely added that as far as the EU was concerned discussions with the United States on the mutual recognition of meat and poultry inspection methods were continuing and Washington's action would not make the talks easier.
"All we ask is that non-EU countries introduce measures that give the same guarantees regarding health protection for EU consumers as our own rules do within the Community," Kiely said.
In addition to $50 million of poultry trade, the U.S. estimates some $50 million worth of U.S. dairy and egg shipments normally sold to the EU will be affected.
Around 100 EU slaughter plants will now have to meet USDA meat inspection standards.
"It's ironic that the U.S. should ban EU meat plants which can meet EU standards which the U.S. has such difficulty complying with," Kiely noted.
Danish pigmeat exports will be most vulnerable to the U.S. curbs.

Industry sources said that U.S. exporters were worried that EU meat hygiene restrictions might trigger similar moves from Russia and eastern European countries which constitute much more important export markets.
